newsitem.title: JAPAN: JAPANESE "VIRTUAL CHICK" TO RUN ON GAME BOYS.
newsitem.headline: JAPANESE "VIRTUAL CHICK" TO RUN ON GAME BOYS.

text.p: Japanese toymaker Bandai Co Ltd said on Tuesday that it would sell a version of its "virtual pet" software for use on Nintendo machines, giving fans a new and more challenging way to play the game.
The "tamagocchi", an electronic bird-like creature on a key-ring display, has been a sell-out success in Japan.
The aim of the game is to raise and nurture the creature, whose lifespan depends on the quality of care provided, using electronic commands.

Bandai said it would supply software for the hit product to run on Nintendo Co Ltd's 8-bit "Game Boy" machine as early as July. This will include the same games as the key-ring type and also allow users to raise a brood of virtual "chicks".
Although Bandai is due to merge with Nintendo rival Sega later this year to create a powerful entertainment entity, it will continue to provide software to run on other game makers' machines.

Bandai has already introduced two types of tamagocchi characters for its key-chain game. The Game Boy software will be able to play both types and will give users the added challenge of raising three of the creatures at once, a Bandai spokeswoman said.
The pet software is expected to retail for 4,286 yen ($35) and will be sold only in Japan, the spokeswoman said. Bandai did not give forecasts for expected sales or profits.

Bandai's tamagocchi has become the latest Japanese craze, selling on the street for more than 20 times its original retail price of 1,980 yen ($16). The name tamagocchi is based on the Japanese word for egg, as the original key-ring type is oval-shaped.
In light of its success here, Bandai announced earlier this month that it would introduce the tamagocchi in Europe, the United States and elsewhere in Asia later this year.
The digital pet can be fed and stroked and "goes to the bathroom" -- in an electronic sense -- just like a live pet. It will "die" if neglected.

Psychologists have said the game, which has been popular with high school students, satisfies nurturing and parenting instincts that can go unfulfilled in a cramped urban environment with limited scope for raising real pets.
Bandai, a major Japanese toy maker also known for the Power Rangers action figures, and Sega Enterprises Ltd announced last month that they would merge in October.
But Bandai president Makoto Yamashina told a news conference on January 23 that the company would maintain its business ties with game makers other than Sega after the merger.

A Sega spokesman said on Tuesday that it does not expect its merger partner's move to affect its business. "We have acknowledged that Bandai plans to continue to supply its software to various game makers," he said. ($1=122 yen)
